speaker: Facebook posts
vclaim: The shooting of El Paso and Dayton was a "fake" attack coordinated by Deep State.
date: stated on August 4, 2019 in Facebook posts:
title: No, mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton were not "false flag" operations.
text: In the morning of August 5, at least 30 people were victims of mass shootings on the weekend in El Paso, Texas, Dayton, Ohio. However, some social media users claim - without evidence - that the tragedies were planned and coordinated by the leftists. The rumors began on Facebook in the morning of August 4 after Dayton was shot. Many Facebook sites claim that the shootings were carried out by Democrats to advance an agenda against weapons prior to the 2020 presidential election. "Communal shootings over the weekend. Both are "paid" efforts by the former state left-wing regime, "claim one post. These articles were referred to as part of Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misleading information in its broadcast. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) After 17 people were shot and killed by a gunman at the Mariory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla, in February 2018, social media users and Russian Posters shared the false claim that the tragedy was staged by a so-called "deep state," an alleged faction within the government that was working against President Donald Trump. Similar tricks were published after the mass shooting in Las Vegas in October 2017. While these attacks revolved around various shootings, false science conspiracies about the attacks in El Paso and Dayton were cut off from the same conspiratorial fabric. One Facebook user posted a photo of the suspect in Dayton along with the alleged armed man at the garlic festival in Gilroy, Califf, last weekend, killing three people. We found similar comparisons side by side on Reddit. On January 10, 2021, in an article on Facebook, he said that Nancy Belusi had sent a letter to the Mayor of Portland after demonstrations there "to demand that he adhere to the proven book of democratic play." The picture on the left comes from a story in the Daily Mill newspaper about Santino William Ligan, 19, which the authorities called the armed man responsible for shooting Gilroy. The picture on the right comes from a KTVT story in Dallas about Patrick Crusious, 21, the suspect associated with El Paso's shooting. The suspect may look alike, but that doesn't mean they're the same person. Authorities in El Paso and Gilroy have identified two different suspects. Besides, Gilroy's authorities said the gunman died at the shooting site. Another article refers to an article from the natural news, a well-known disinfectant of health, which allegedly shows that "the official story of the mass shooting in El Paso and the Mart is largely fabricated." Polyte Fact did not assess each of the five points raised by the site, but the article depends on speculation and speculation in the allegation that the shootings in El Paso and Dayton were false. Furthermore, there is no evidence to suggest that the attack was either coordinated or planned by a left-wing faction of the United States Government. The authorities are investigating a statement published on the Internet by the alleged armed El Paso shortly before the attack, which expressed hatred and attacked the Spanish people in the United States. The police have yet to reveal a possible motive for the shooter in Dayton, who was killed at the scene, but media reports indicate that 24-year-old Connor Bates spoke of violent fantasies in the past. Our ruling article on social media claims that the shooting of El Paso and Dayton was a "fake" attack coordinated by the Deep State. Publications use a combination of speculation and misleading information to arrive at an unproven conclusion. We're assessing this pants claim on fire.
